results.title: Belles of the south seas
results.brief_description: Documentary travelogue view of the south sea islands and their native peoples. Includes Tahiti, New Zealand (South Island), Fiji, Samoan Islands, Papua and Kalabahi.

results.title: Belle epoque = Age of beauty
results.creator_credit: Fernando Trueba, Andres Gomes, Animatografia, Lola Films and Fernando Trueba P.C.
results.brief_description: During the Spanish Civil War, Fernando (Jorge Sanz), an army deserter, wanders into the sprawling property inhabited by a painter (Fernando Fernan Gomez) and his four free-spirited daughters (Penelope Cruz, Ariadna Gil, Miriam Diaz-Aroca, Maribel Verdu). Delighted to have found a brother in pacifism, Manolo invites the young man to stay on. His sojourn will be a succession of sunny days, shared friendships, and games of seduction as Manolo’s four daughters all vie for Fernando’s attention. This sexy film, a celebration of all the pleasures life has to offer, is illuminated by the beauty of the four lead actresses and a sensual photography. (Awards: Winner of the Oscar for Best Foreign Film in 1994) In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Belle de Jour
results.creator_credit: Luis Bunuel, Raymond Hakim, Betty Edmonds, Robert Edmonds, Five Films and Paris Film
results.brief_description: Catherine Deneuve plays a beautiful young woman married to a rich young surgeon (Jean Sorel). Their life is a material success but the wife’s frigidity is a strain on the marriage. Plagued by masochistic sexual fantasies, she takes a part-time job in a brothel, hoping that by playing the part of Belle de Jour, the high class prostitute, she can overcome her dislike for sex. This is a savagely funny, and often a very cruel film, as it pulls apart the consumerist psyche of a bourgeois woman to reveal her as souless and empty of life. Stripped of her clothes, her jewellery, her status, she is a no-one. It is only as Belle de Jour that she can emotionally experience life. The movie moves back and forth from the casual filmwork of the brothel scenes to the surrealist dream sequences where Belle de Jour recieves the punishments she feels she deserves. Though often criticised as a misogynist film, it is not women who are the target of Bunuel’s satire, but the pretensions of wealth and status. Nor is the sexuality of men sacred for Bunuel as some of the funniest sequences deal with the absurdities of masculine desire. Co-starring Michel Piccoli and Genevieve Page. Based on the novel by Jospeh Kessel.

results.title: Bellamy's Daintree: where reef meets rainforest
results.creator_credit: Australian Conservation Foundation and Wilderness Society
results.brief_description: David Bellamy shows how quickly our rainforests - the most diverse living system on land - are disappearing. He then catalogues the reasons why we should not be destroying our few remaining rainforests including genetic reserves retained in these forests.
results.description: David Bellamy shows how quickly our rainforests - the most diverse living system on land - are disappearing. He then catalogues the reasons why we should not be destroying our few remaining rainforests including genetic reserves retained in these forests.

results.title: Belinda (A)
results.creator_credit: Peter Thompson, Jack Lee, Save the Children Fund and Trojan Films
results.brief_description: Chronicles the first few days of a three year old Aboriginal girl at a preschool kindergarten in Walgett, N.S.W. Shows the growth in trust between teacher and child until the girl and her mother disappear on walkabout.

results.title: Belgium and the Netherlands
results.brief_description: A survey of Belgium and the Netherlands, their relationship to each other and to their neighbours. Explains how their culture and economy are affected by environmental factors such as easy access to the North Sea, their small size and dense population and their coal resources. No other credits available.

results.title: Belgium
results.creator_credit: Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description: A skipper of a barge who travels the canals and rivers of Belgium tells about Belgium, describing its role as a historic invasion route since the days of Caesar. Discusses the country’s bi-lingual system, contrasts the fertile Flanders with the industrial south, and shows the importance of Antwerp as a European harbour.

results.title: Belch
results.creator_credit: Lesley Pinder and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Buried in the outer suburbs of Melbourne it appears many subcultures are alive and well. Just ask Bill Hudson (Ian Thomas), the pride of the town, who for the past three years won the coveted Burping Competition. Although great burps run in the family the daughter Jo (Alex Schepisi) struggles to be accepted as she is unable to burp. Made to feel an outcast she goes to great lengths to change her predicament and prove herself as worthy. Other cast members include: Marie-Theresa Byrne, Michael Gwynne, Stuart Baker, Morgan Evans and Renato Bartolomei.

results.title: Bekevar Jubilee
results.creator_credit: Albert Kish, Roman Kroitor, William Weintraub and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A warm and lively film, Bekevar Jubilee dips back into history to look at a time when the first Hungarian peasants came to settle the plains of Saskatchewan. The film documents the festivities commemorating the 75th anniversary of the Bekevar community, and contrasts it with footage and photographs of the old - and new - countries at the turn of the century.

results.title: Bejart's Kabuki Ballet
results.creator_credit: Kiichiro Ito, Kanae Mayuzumi and Nihon Hoso Kyokai
results.brief_description: Traces the preparation for Marcel Bejart’s ballet production of “Chushingura” that was commissioned by the Tokyo Ballet in 1985 and saw a fusion between European ballet and Japanese Kabuki theatre. Choreographed by Bejart, the ballet was a simplification of a popular 9 hour Kabuki play based on a real incident in Japanese history of a group of 47 samurai who avenged the murder of their master and then committed ritual suicide. Bejart created harmony between the traditional Japanese theatrical form and European ballet through the incorporation of Kabuki gestures, movement techniques and props in the ballet’s choreography. Through the synthesis of dance and traditional Japanese costumes and the integration of Kabuki dance and theatre music into the orchestral composition that was to accompany the ballet. A ground breaking production for its unique combination of seemingly disparate performance cultures, “Chushingura” was the result of detailed research into the history of Kabuki theatre and dance and consultation with contemporary practitioners of the form. In footage of rehearsals and in interviews with Bejart and the Tokyo Ballet dancers, this process is discussed along with the themes that Bejart was exploring in the preparation for and final production of the ballet, complimented by mirrored sequences depicting a Kabuki performance of the popular tale and Bejart’s ballet. This documentary was also the Grand Prix Winner of the International Emmy Awards in 1986.
